<p><em>This was the first contribution I’ve ever made at <a href="https://github.com/jquery/learn.jquery.com/pull/88">GitHub</a>, belonging to the original<br> <a href="http://learn.jquery.com">learn.jquery.com</a> website. The original article is now offline, but saved here for the future.</em></p> <p>Arrays are zero-indexed, ordered lists of values. They are a handy way to store a set of<br> related items of the same type (such as strings), though in reality, an array<br> can include multiple types of items, including other arrays.</p> <p>To create an array you can either use the object constructor or the literal declaration,<br> by assigning your variable a list of values right after the declaration.</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// A simple array var myArray1 = new Array( 'hello', 'world' ); // with constructor var myArray2 = [ 'hello', 'world' ]; // literal declaration, the preferred way </code></pre> <p>The literal declaration is preferred, see the<br> <a href="http://google-styleguide.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/javascriptguide.xml#Array_and_Object_literals">Google Coding Guidelines</a><br> for more information.</p> <p>If you don’t know your values yet, it is also possible to declare an empty Array, and<br> add elements either through functions or through accessing by index:</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// Creating empty arrays and adding values var myArray = []; myArray.push('hello'); // adds 'hello' on index 0 myArray.push('world'); // adds 'world' on index 1 myArray[2] = '!'; // adds '!' on index 2 </code></pre> <p>‘push’ is a function which adds an element on the end of the array and expands the array<br> respectively. You also can directly add items by index. Missing indices will be filled<br> with ‘undefined’;</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// Leaving indices var myArray = []; myArray[0] = 'hello'; myArray[1] = 'world'; myArray[3] = '!'; console.log(myArray); // logs ['hello', 'world', undefined, '!']; </code></pre> <p>So ‘push’ is far more safe, especially if you don’t know the size of your<br> array yet. With the index you not only assign values to array items, but also<br> access those.</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// Accessing array items by index var myArray = [ 'hello', 'world', '!']; console.log(myArray[2]); // logs '!' </code></pre> <h2>Array methods and properties</h2> <h3>length</h3> <p>The ‘length’ property is used to know the amount of items in your array.</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// Length of an array var myArray = [ 'hello', 'world', '!']; console.log(myArray.length); // logs 3 </code></pre> <p>You will need the length property for looping through an array:</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// For loops and arrays - a classic var myArray = ['hello', 'world', '!']; for(var i = 0; i &lt; myArray.length; i = i + 1) { console.log(myArray[i]); } </code></pre> <p>Except when you are using for … in loops:</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// or loops and arrays - alternate method var myArray = ['hello', 'world', '!']; for(var i in myArray) { console.log(myArray[i]); } </code></pre> <h3>concat</h3> <p>With ‘concat’, you can concatenate two or more arrays</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// Concatenating Arrays var myArray = [2, 3, 4]; var myOtherArray = [5, 6, 7]; var wholeArray = myArray.concat(myOtherArray); // [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7] </code></pre> <h3>join</h3> <p>‘join’ creates a string representation of your array. It’s parameter is as string<br> which works as a seperator between elements (default is a comma);</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// Joining elements var myArray = ['hello', 'world', '!']; console.log(myArray.join(' ')); // logs &quot;hello world !&quot;; console.log(myArray.join()); // logs &quot;hello,world,!&quot; console.log(myArray.join('')); // logs &quot;helloworld!&quot; console.log(myArray.join('!!')) // logs &quot;hello!!world!!!!!&quot;; </code></pre> <h3>pop</h3> <p>‘pop’ removes the last element of an array. It is the opposite method to ‘push’</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// pushing and popping var myArray = []; myArray.push(0); // [ 0 ] myArray.push(2); // [ 0 , 2 ] myArray.push(7); // [ 0 , 2 , 7 ] myArray.pop(); // [ 0 , 2 ] </code></pre> <h3>reverse</h3> <p>As the name suggests, the elements of the array are in reverse order after calling<br> this method</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// reverse var myArray = [ 'world' , 'hello' ]; myArray.reverse(); // [ 'hello', 'world' ] </code></pre> <h3>shift</h3> <p>Removes the first element of an array. With ‘pop’ and ‘shift’ you can recreate the<br> method of a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queue_(data_structure)">queue</a></p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// queue with shift() and pop() var myArray = []; myArray.push(0); // [ 0 ] myArray.push(2); // [ 0 , 2 ] myArray.push(7); // [ 0 , 2 , 7 ] myArray.shift(); // [ 2 , 7 ] </code></pre> <h3>slice</h3> <p>Extracts a part of the array and returns them in a new one. This method takes one<br> parameter, which is the starting index.</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// slicing var myArray = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]; var newArray = myArray.slice(3); console.log(myArray); // [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8] console.log(newArray); // [4, 5, 6, 7, 8] </code></pre> <h3>splice</h3> <p>Removes a certain amount of elements and adds new ones at the given index. It takes<br> at least 3 parameters</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// splice method myArray.splice(idx, len, values, ...); </code></pre> <ul> <li>idx = the starting index</li> <li>len = the number of elements to remove</li> <li>values = the values which should be inserted at idx</li> </ul> <p>For example:</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// splice example var myArray = [0, 7, 8, 5]; myArray.splice(1, 2, 1, 2, 3, 4); console.log(myArray); // [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5] </code></pre> <h3>sort</h3> <p>Sorts an array. It takes one parameter, which is a comparing function. If this function is not<br> given, the array is sorted ascending</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// sorting without comparing function var myArray = [3, 4, 6, 1]; myArray.sort(); // 1, 3, 4, 6 </code></pre> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// sorting with comparing function function descending(a, b) { return b - a; } var myArray = [3, 4, 6, 1]; myArray.sort(descending); // [6, 4, 3, 1] </code></pre> <p>The return value of descending (for this example) is important. If the return value is<br> less than zero, the index of a is before b, and if it is greater than zero it’s vice-versa.<br> If the return value is zero, the elements index is equal.</p> <h3>unshift</h3> <p>Inserts an element at the first position of the array</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// unshift var myArray = []; myArray.unshift(0); // [ 0 ] myArray.unshift(2); // [ 2 , 0 ] myArray.unshift(7); // [ 7 , 2 , 0 ] </code></pre> <h3>forEach</h3> <p>In modern browsers, like Chrome, Firefox and Internet Explorer 9 it is possible to traverse<br> through arrays by a so called ‘forEach’ method, where you pass a function which is called<br> for each element in your array.</p> <p>The function takes up to three arguments:</p> <ul> <li>element - The element itself</li> <li>index - The index of this element in the array</li> <li>array - The array itself</li> </ul> <p>All of the are optional, but you will need at least the ‘element’ parameter in most cases.</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">// native forEach function printElement(elem) { console.log(elem); } function printElementAndIndex(elem, index) { console.log(&quot;Index &quot; + index + &quot;: &quot; + elem); } function negateElement(elem, index, array) { array[index] = -elem; } myArray = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; myArray.forEach(printElement); //prints all elements to the console myArray.forEach(printElementAndIndex); //prints &quot;Index 0: 1&quot; &quot;Index 1: 2&quot; &quot;Index 2: 3&quot; ... myArray.forEach(negateElement); // myArray is now [-1, -2, -3, -4, -5] </code></pre>
